wikipedia_page.main: James Louis Fitzroy Scott Douglas (born in Malmesbury, Wiltshire 24 October 1930, died 16 July 1969) was a British racing driver, as well as a Baronet.

Her father died from pneumonia on 22 March 1922, whilst recuperating in South Africa following a riding accident, leaving issue two daughters. His earldom and associated titles thus passed to his first cousin.  Her mother, the widowed Countess, remarried George Francis Valentine Scott Douglas and had a son James Louis Fitzroy Scott Douglas (1930-1969), later Sir James Scott Douglas, Bt GRO Register of Births: DEC 1930 5a 76 MALMESBURY - James L F S Douglas, mmn=Somerset by her second husband; this half-brother died unmarried.
*James Scott Douglas (1930–1969) Scottish racing driver (and Baronet Douglas)
*James Scott Douglas – racing driver and the 6th Baronet Douglas

Although two of the three works Ferraris had retired during the race, Scuderia victory was never seriously threatened. After Fangio/Sanesi accident after only 22 laps, the Ferrari was without any close competition. Farina and Hawthorn would remain in the lead throughout the whole race, even when the rain came late on in the race. At the finish, Farina and Hawthorn had an 18 lap advantage over the Jaguar C-Type of the Scottish Ecurie Ecosse. In the end, the Ferrari margin of victory amounted to about an advantage of close to 90 minutes over James Scott Douglas and Guy Gale. A Belgian-entered Jaguar C-Type of Herman Roosdorp and Toni Ulmen was a further eleven laps down and finished third. In the touring car class, the Portuguese driver Viegas Vellagao and his Belgian co-driver, Vladimir Narichkine were victorious in their Mercedes-Benz 220. However, although they were fifth overall, they were 68 laps behind the winning Ferrari. The winning partnership, won in a time of 24hr 02:07.085mins., averaging a speed of 94.910 mph. They covered a distance of 2,281.182 miles.

Guy was a competent racing driver who raced mainly between 1949 and 1953.http://www.racingsportscars.com/driver/results/Guy-Gale.html During these years, recording a number of good results, including six wins and 22 podiums finishes, with the majority of these at national events.http://www.racingsportscars.com/driver/results/Guy-Gale.html His greatest racing achievement, when partnered by James Scott Douglas, he finished second in the 1953 24 Heures de Spa Francorchamps.
